Alignments of structures containing 199 tRNAs in several configurations (canonical tRNAs PDBID:4V5D[42], with 200 A/T-tRNA PDBID:5LZS[43] and hybrid tRNAs PDBID:3J7R[44]) with the 201 structure of the IAPV-IRES in complex with the 40S, reveal an interesting 202 positioning of the straight unit formed by SL-III and the ASL-like part of 203 PKI (Fig. 3C). Similarly, PKIII overlaps with the position occupied by a hybrid P/E-207 tRNA, mimicking its helical components the elbow region of a tRNA in this 208 intermediate configuration. Overall, the IAPV-IRES is able to manipulate 209 the 40S subunit in isolation, blocking the functional sites where key canonical 210 initiation factors bind, and at the same time, steering the intrinsic dynamics 211 of the 40S head towards a configuration reminiscent of an early elongation,

FIGREF7.text: L1.1 region and the A site finger and the ribosomal protein uL16 the SL-III. The A site finger (28S rRNA helix 38) is a flexible component of 228 the 28S rRNA which plays an important role in translocation of tRNAs from 229 the A to the P site [46]. In many structures is not visible due to its intrinsic 230 flexibility, required to perform its role escorting in-transit tRNAs [46, 47]. 231 The SL-III of IAPV-IRES contacts the A site finger, stabilizing it in a fixed 232 conformation, which allows the apical loop of SL-III to reach deep into the 233 60S, establishing a novel interaction with the ribosomal protein uL16 (Fig. 234 4B and C). The IAPV-IRES positions the apical loop of SL-III (nucleotides 235 6585 to 6590) in direct contact with basic residues of uL16, which are in 236 electrostatic interacting distance with negatively charged phosphates of the 237 RNA backbone of the IRES (Fig. 4C). The additional anchoring points to 238 the ribosome contributed by SL-III, allows the IAPV-IRES, in the context 239 of a 80S interaction, to be stabilized in a conformation that overlaps with 240 the space occupied by a hybrid A/P-tRNA. The coaxial unit SL-III/ASL-241 like domain of the IAPV-IRES functionally mimmics a A/P-tRNA priming 242 the 80S for eEF2 recruitment, effectively bypassing the initiation stage (Fig. 243 4D). Additionally, the anchoring points provided by the IAPV-IRES along 244 the intersubunit space, probably contribute to an effective recruitment of the 245 60S in the absence of the dedicated factor responsible for such function in 246 canonical translation, eIF5B [48].

FIGREF8.text: IRESs restricts the small subunit rotation 248 dynamics in the pre-translocation state. 249 No populations with wide rotations of the small subunit were identified in 250 our 80S/IAPV-IRES large dataset, what suggests that, in contrast with 251 Cripavirus IRES's [49, 30], the IAPV-IRES is able to restrict the dynamic 252 of the small subunit, channeling it towards a canonical, non-rotated con-253 figuration. This is accomplished by a solid anchoring of the PKI in the A 254 site, which not only mimics the ASL of a tRNA interacting with its cognate 255 mRNA in the A site, but also, by placing the SL-III in a similar position as 256 a hybrid A/P-tRNA [50, 51], mimics the T and D arms (Fig. 4D and Fig. 257 5B). In such position, the PKI of the IAPV-IRES establishes a network of 258 interactions with both the large and the small subunit, effectively restricting 259 the rotation of the 40S. Apart from the interactions stablished by the apical 260 loop of the SL-III with ribosomal protein uL16 (Fig. 4C), the decoding event 261 elicited by the placement of the PKI in the decoding center allows the estab-262 lishment of an interaction with the 28S rRNA base A3760 (A1913 in E.coli ), 263 normally involved in decoding (Fig. 5C) [52].

The IAPV-IRES seems to bind 266 very tightly in a binary, pre-translocation complex with the 80S. The re-267 cruitment of elongation factors to commit the ribosome to the production of 268 viral proteins seems to be achieved not through a dynamic manipulation of 269 the 40S rotation, but by directly adopting a configuration reminiscent of a 270 ribosome with tRNAs in hybrid configurations. 271 Remodeling of specific components of the IAPV-IRES 272 allows its translocation through the ribosome. 273 Due to their intrinsic flexibility, IRESs are able to populate multiple con-274 formational states, while maintaining a basic structural framework dictated 275 by their base pairing scheme. A combination of rigid elements connected 276 via flexible linkers allow these RNAs to tune their interactions with differ-277 ent ribosomal sites as they transit from an early pre-translocated state to 278 a post-translocated one. Along this vectorial movement, these IRESs take 279 advantage of intrinsic dynamic elements of the ribosome, normally involved 280 in translocation of tRNAs and mRNAs [53, 23]. 281 In order to visualize the IAPV-IRES in a post-translocated state, we engi-282 neered a stop codon in the first coding codon following the IRES sequence 283 [26, 54]. By simultaneously incubating a pre-translocated 80S/IAPV-IRES 284 complex with eEF2 and a catalytically inactive version of the eukaryotic re-285 lease factor 1 (eRF1*) [55] in the presence of GTP, we were able to stabilize 286 the IRES after a single translocation on the ribosome, allowing the visual-287 ization of the overall conformation of the IRES in a post-translocated state 288 as well as the specific determinants of the IRES in binding the ribosomal P 289 site (Fig. 6). 290 Globally, the post-translocated IAPV-IRES exhibits an extended confor-291 mation with the ASL/SL-III unit deeply inserted in the P site and the L1.1 292 region maintaining its original connection with the L1-stalk. On the right, equivalent view with canonical tRNAs. being the Dicistrovirideae family of viruses of special interest given its wide range and distribution of hosts [2, 9]. 343 Within this complex scenario, intricate population dynamics are stablished 344 between RNA viruses, hosts and vectors, with unpredictable outcomes like 345 decimation of entire populations, able to reshape the species compositional 346 landscape. An example of such intricate scenario is the current collapse of bee 347 hives worldwide, a syndrome termed Colony Collapse Disorder or CCD. Even 348 thought the exact cause of CCD could be multi-faceted and complex, there is 349 unambiguous evidence that a related group of bee-infecting RNA viruses of 350 the Dicistrovirideae family exert a deleterious effect [1, 2, 8]. Viruses of this 351 family make use of a RNA-only mechanism to take control of host ribosomes 352 in order to gain access to the cellular machinery for protein production [31]. 353 Using cryo-EM, we comprehensively characterized how the intergenic IRES 354 of IAPV, a putative agent causing CCD, binds and manipulate ribosomes to 355 redirect them toward the production of viral proteins. The IAPV-IRES is 356 able to establish a stable binary interaction with the small ribosomal sub-357 unit. An early capturing of free 40S subunits, committing them toward viral 358 protein production, may represent a limiting step in a cellular environment 359 where competition between cellular and viral messengers content for riboso-360 mal access. The IAPV-IRES is able to insert its PKI domain in the A site 361 (decoding site) of the 40S effectively blocking the binding of eIF1/eIF1A, two 362 initiation factors required for canonical initiation (Fig. 2C). While blocking 363 the 40S functional sites, the IAPV-IRES is able to steerer the intrinsic dy-364 namic of the 40S subunit towards a specific configuration, facilitating the 365 recruitment of the large ribosomal subunit (60S) in the absence of eIF5B, 366 the cellular factor catalyzing this event (Fig. 4A). 367 Bypassing the highly regulated initiation stage of translation is a custom-368 ary requirement for the type IV family of IRES [18]. This is accomplished 369 by inducing an altered ribosome stage, able to recruit directly and without 370 tRNAs, elongation factors (eEF2 and eEF1A). Cripavirus IRESs like the 371 CrPV-IRES, accomplish this by inducing a wide rotation on the 40S, mim-372

The limited 376 dynamic of 40S subunit rotation observed in our large cryo-EM dataset re-377 flects a solid anchoring of both ribosomal subunits, mediated mainly by the 378 additional contacts contributed by the SL-III characteristic of this family of 379 IRESs.

FIGREF13.text: Type IV IRES families exploit different pre-translocation features of canonical translation for ribosome hijacking. (Top) The Cripavirus family of Type IV IRESs is able to capture free 40S subunits and engage them on a pre-translocation complex by recruiting 60S. This complex is extremely dynamic, with the 40S alternating between non-rotated and rotated configurations respect the 60S subunit. IRESs belonging to this family, exemplified by the CrPV-IRES, recruit elongation factors by mimicking a rotated stated of the ribosome with tRNAS. (Bottom), The Aparavirus family of IRESs follows a similar pathway in order to assemble a pre-translocation complex, however, specific structural components of this family allow for additional contacts with the 60S, limiting the rotational freedom of the 40S. After translocation, and once PKI is 393 displaced to the P site, the VRL is extended, contacting ribosomal protein 394 uS7, a component of the 40S subunit's E site (Fig. 6E). Biochemical evi-395 dence support a key role of the VRL in IRES function, as mutations and/or 396 shortening impacts the ability of the IRES to efficiently translocate [36].397Using high resolution single-particle cryo-EM analysis, we showed how the398 prototypical Aparavirus IRES of the intergenic region of the IAPV manip-399 ulates the eukaryotic ribosome to position a viral non-AUG codon in the 400 ribosomal A site to effectively hijack the host machinery for protein produc-401 tion. We have uncovered a new strategy of early pre-translocation mimicry 402 used by this IRES sub-family as well as visualize the conformational dynamic 403 of a strategic single-stranded segment of the IRES, the VRL. The structures 404 presented here will allow structure-based design of new and better RNA in-405 terfering strategies directed toward the vital intergenic IRES of the IAPV. 406 Ongoing efforts in that direction have already proved successful in fighting 407 CCD, protecting bee hives from collapse [33, 60].
